body:
Add a new field `virt_lines_overflow` that enables horizontal scrolling
for virtual lines when set to "scroll".

Ref https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/18282#issuecomment-2667771187
Close #31000

comment_data.body: Why don't we make `false` work like this?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2649,8 +2649,14 @@ nvim_buf_set_extmark({buffer}, {ns_id}, {line}, {col}, {opts})
                     lines are placed below the buffer line containing the
                     mark.
                   • virt_lines_above: place virtual lines above instead.
-                  • virt_lines_leftcol: Place virtual lines in the leftmost
-                    column of the window, bypassing sign and number columns.
+                  • virt_lines_leftcol: Can be a boolean or the string
+                    "sidescroll".
+                    • `false`: virtual lines start after sign and number
+                      columns, etc..
+                    • `true`: virtual lines start at the leftmost column of
+                      the window.
+                    • "sidescroll": with 'nowrap' virtual lines can be
+                      scrolled horizontally, otherwise the same as `false`.

comment_data.body: Do you mean like how `spell` currently works? That may be a bit confusing, since `leftcol` can also refer to the current horizontal scrolling offset of a window (as in `winsaveview()` and `getwininfo()`), so one would expect `virt_lines_leftcol = false` to disable horizontal scrolling.

comment_data.body:
Maybe allowing horizontal scrolling if and only if `virt_lines_leftcol` is omitted makes more sense?
- Most plugins don't explicitly specify `virt_lines_leftcol = false`.
- For plugins that want horizontal scrolling but don't currently handle it, they'll automatically get support for horizontally scrolling.
- For plugins that manually handle horizontal scrolling, they'll have to disable the manual handling for Nvim 0.11.
- For plugins that don't want horizontally scrolling, they'll have to add `virt_lines_leftcol = false`, which also works the same in previous Nvim versions.

Not sure if this means adding this to the BREAKING CHANGES section though, or having it in the CHANGED FEATURES section is enough.

I find the name of this variable quite obscure and not very intuitive:

- `virt_lines_leftcol=false` positions the extmark relative to the leftmost column of the buffer.
- `virt_lines_leftcol=true` positions the extmark relative to the leftmost column of the window.

comment_regular_data.body: TBH I'm not entirely sure about `virt_lines_leftcol`, as it may be a bit confusing. Having a separate `virt_lines_sidescroll` flag may be less confusing. With a separate `virt_lines_sidescroll` flag, plugins that want horizontal scrolling need to check for Nvim 0.11 before adding the flag, as older Nvim versions don't allow the flag.

I tried this patch on top of 0.10.4 and the virtual lines diagnostics don't scroll for me.

I'll try the master branch when I have a bit more spare time.
I've now updated this PR following <https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/18282#issuecomment-2667771187>, but does the `none` value name sound a bit strange?

> I've now updated this PR following [#18282 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/18282#issuecomment-2667771187), but does the `none` value name sound a bit strange?

Maybe a bit, but otherwise sounds more or less like "do nothing to react to overflow". Couple of other ideas: `'fix'` / `'fixed'` (doesn't react to overflow), `'trunc'` (which follows the current "truncate virtual lines from the right" description).
On second thought, `trunc` is indeed more accurate.
